hints.content:
There's a lot of good thinking in Hadley's work. They can keep an expression equal and still break apart or group the factors.

Let's find where Hadley changed the value of the expression.

###Step 1

$5\times \redE{4{,}000} \overset{\checkmark}{=}5\times \redE{4 \times 1{,}000}$

Hadley broke apart the factors of ${4{,}000}$ correctly.

###Step 3

$\begin{align}
5\times{4{,}000} &={5 \times 4} \times 1{,}000\\\\
&= \goldE{20 \times 1{,}000}\\\\
&=\goldE{20{,}000}\\\\
&\neq {2{,}000}
\end{align}$

Hadley did *not* group the factors $20$ and $1{,}000$ correctly.
Hadley made a mistake in step 3.
